normalised: **Environmental News: Mumbai Tackles Growing Waste Crisis with New Initiative**

unnormalised: **Environmental News: Mumbai Tackles Growing Waste Crisis with New Initiative**
normalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra – The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (B M C) today announced a comprehensive new initiative aimed at improving waste management across the city, addressing mounting concerns about overflowing landfills and their environmental impact.

unnormalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra – The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) today announced a comprehensive new initiative aimed at improving waste management across the city, addressing mounting concerns about overflowing landfills and their environmental impact.
normalised: The project, budgeted at rupee five hundred crore, will focus on decentralised waste processing units in each of Mumbai's twenty four wards, reducing the burden on the Deonar and Mulund dumping grounds. Inspired by the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan and subtly echoing the themes explored in films like 'Toilet: Ek Prem Katha', the program emphasizes citizen participation and segregation at source.

unnormalised: The project, budgeted at Rs. 500 crore, will focus on decentralised waste processing units in each of Mumbai’s 24 wards, reducing the burden on the Deonar and Mulund dumping grounds. Inspired by the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan and subtly echoing the themes explored in films like 'Toilet: Ek Prem Katha', the program emphasizes citizen participation and segregation at source.
normalised: Doctor Anjali Sharma, Head of the Environmental Studies department at I I T Bombay, lauded the effort, stating that “effective implementation will be key to its success, particularly in densely populated areas like Dharavi and Bandra.” The B M C plans to utilise technology for real-time monitoring of waste collection and transportation, streamlining operations and ensuring greater accountability. The initiative targets a fifty percent reduction in landfill waste within five years, transforming Mumbai into a cleaner, more sustainable city. Further, the B M C will develop ten new compost plants within a radius of twenty kilometer from city center.
